Mass. senators offer plan to oversee MBTA finances

Three state senators -- one Republican and two Democrats -- are calling for an independent board to oversee the finances of the ailing MBTA. (AP, 10:18 a.m.)
  • Pictures Changes to expect from the MBTA
  • Transit cuts threaten public health, report says
  • Submit Suggest a new slogan for the MBTA

US job openings lowest in 5 months

The Labor Department said job openings fell to 3.4 million in April, down from 3.7 million in March, suggesting hiring will remain sluggish. (AP, 11:50 a.m.)
  • Stocks move higher on hopes of Fed action

Poll: Voters approve of Obama's immigration order by 2 to 1 margin

Almost two-thirds of likely voters approve of President Obama's order to allow some young illegal immigrants to stay in the US, a Bloomberg poll found. (Globe, 11:41 a.m.)
  • O'Malley hails Obama's decision on illegal immigrants

Mainstream media barred from BIO event

The Biotechnology Industry Organization's keynote event will feature former treasury secretaries Henry Paulson Jr. and Robert Rubin. (Globe, 12:05 p.m.)

Federal government launches database tracking credit card complaints

The new database goes live today and allows users to view complaints against banks that issue cards. (AP)

News

Colorado wildfire half contained

A wildfire that has charred nearly 92 square miles destroyed at least 189 homes - the most in the state's history - in northern Colorado since it began 10 days ago is now 50 percent contained, authorities said.

Microsoft's tortured tablet history

For decades, the tablet computer was like a mirage in the technology industry: a great idea, that was seemingly reachable on the horizon. Microsoft has experienced this cycle of hope and disappointment many times.

Save money on groceries

Although it may not seem like it, food costs are still one of the most flexible areas in most families' budgets. While you may have little control over your mortgage or day care costs, you can probably save money on groceries.
